welcomeScreen.subtitle: A hands-on 4-hour workshop where you'll learn to create stunning 3D visualizations and interactive experiences using CSS 3D transforms and Three.js.

features.description: Progressive learning from CSS 3D to Three.js

features.title: Real Projects
features.description: Build cubes, terrain, and particle galaxies

sections.title: üë• Target Persona
items: Frontend Developers who want to add 3D graphics to their skill set.
Creative Developers looking to build immersive web experiences.
Web Designers wanting to understand 3D visualization techniques.

sections.title: ü§î The Reasoning
sections.content: 3D graphics on the web are no longer limited to games - they're everywhere! From product visualizations to data displays, knowing 3D opens up a world of creative possibilities. We start with CSS 3D to build intuition, then move to Three.js for professional-grade graphics.

sections.title: üéØ Outcomes
items: Mastery of CSS 3D Transforms for interface effects.
Understanding of Three.js fundamentals - scenes, cameras, renderers.
Ability to create 3D materials and lighting for realistic visuals.
Confidence in building particle systems and procedural generation.

sections.title: üß† The Strategy
sections.content: We use a "Build-First" approach. You'll create visual 3D projects from the start, learning concepts through hands-on coding. Each exercise builds on the previous one, taking you from CSS basics to advanced Three.js techniques.

sections.title: üìö Format & Modules
sections.content: The 4-hour curriculum is split into 4 distinct hours:
items: Hour 1: CSS 3D - Flip cards, rotating cubes, pure CSS transforms.
Hour 2: Three.js Basics - Scenes, geometries, materials, lighting.
Hour 3: Advanced Shapes - Complex geometries, camera controls.
Hour 4: Procedural Magic - Terrain generation, particle systems.

exercises.title: CSS 3D Card
exercises.preambleTitle: Welcome to 3D Graphics on the Web!
exercises.preambleIntro: In this first exercise, you'll learn how to create 3D transformations using pure CSS. No external libraries needed - just the power of CSS 3D transforms!
keyConcepts: perspective: Creates depth and 3D space for child elements
transform-style: preserve-3d: Maintains 3D positioning of nested elements
backface-visibility: Controls visibility of the back of an element
commonPitfalls: Forgetting to set perspective on the parent container
Not using transform-style: preserve-3d for nested 3D elements
Mixing 2D and 3D transforms incorrectly
Not considering the transform-origin when rotating
exercises.prerequisites: Basic CSS knowledge. We'll build up your 3D skills step by step!
exercises.description: Create a 3D flip card using CSS transforms. Learn perspective, 3D rotations, and how to create depth with pure CSS.
objectives: Create 3D rotations with rotateX, rotateY, rotateZ
Build an interactive flip card with front and back faces
exercises.starterCode:
Front
Back
exercises.solution:
Front
Back
exercises.hint: Set perspective: 1000px on the container, transform-style: preserve-3d on the card, and rotate the card with transform: rotateY(180deg) on hover. Don't forget to rotate the back face 180deg initially!

exercises.title: 3D Cube Rotation
exercises.preambleIntro: Now let's level up by creating a full 3D cube that rotates continuously. This exercise teaches you how to position multiple faces in 3D space and create smooth animations.
keyConcepts: translateZ: Moves elements along the Z-axis (toward/away from viewer)
commonPitfalls: Incorrect translateZ distance (should be half the cube size)
Forgetting to rotate faces before translating them
Not centering the cube properly
Animation running too fast or too slow
exercises.prerequisites: Understanding of CSS 3D transforms from the previous exercise.
exercises.description: Create a 3D cube with 6 faces that rotates continuously. Learn how to position elements in 3D space and create smooth animations.
objectives: Position faces using translateZ and rotate

exercises.title: Three.js Scene Setup
exercises.preambleIntro: Three.js is the most popular 3D library for the web. It provides a powerful, easy-to-use API for creating and displaying 3D graphics. Let's set up your first scene!
keyConcepts: Camera: The viewpoint from which we see the scene
Renderer: Renders the scene to the canvas
Mesh: Combines geometry and material into a renderable object
commonPitfalls: Forgetting to add objects to the scene
Not positioning the camera correctly (too close or inside objects)
Not calling renderer.render() in the animation loop
Forgetting to append the canvas to the document body
exercises.prerequisites: Basic JavaScript knowledge. No prior 3D experience needed!
exercises.description: Set up a basic Three.js scene with a camera, renderer, and a rotating cube. This is the foundation for all Three.js projects.

exercises.solution:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Three.js Scene</title>
  <style>
    body { margin: 0; overflow: hidden; }
    canvas { display: block; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/three@0.160.0/build/three.min.js"></script>
  <script>
    const scene = new THREE.Scene();
    const camera = new THREE.PerspectiveCamera(75, window.innerWidth / window.innerHeight, 0.1, 1000);
    const renderer = new THREE.WebGLRenderer();
    
    renderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
    document.body.appendChild(renderer.domElement);
    
    const geometry = new THREE.BoxGeometry(1, 1, 1);
    const material = new THREE.MeshBasicMaterial({ color: 0x00ff00 });
    const cube = new THREE.Mesh(geometry, material);
    scene.add(cube);
    
    camera.position.z = 5;
    
    function animate() {
      requestAnimationFrame(animate);
      cube.rotation.x += 0.01;
      cube.rotation.y += 0.01;
      renderer.render(scene, camera);
    }
    
    animate();
  </script>
</body>
</html>
exercises.hint: Create a scene, camera, and renderer. Add a BoxGeometry with a MeshBasicMaterial. In the animate function, rotate the cube and call renderer.render(scene, camera).

exercises.title: 3D Materials & Lighting
exercises.preambleIntro: Learn how to add realistic lighting and materials to your 3D scenes. Lighting transforms flat objects into realistic 3D visuals with depth and dimension.
keyConcepts: AmbientLight: Provides soft, uniform lighting across the scene
MeshStandardMaterial: Physically-based material that reacts to light
Metalness & Roughness: Properties that control material appearance
Light Positioning: How light position affects shadows and highlights
commonPitfalls: Using MeshBasicMaterial which doesn't react to lights
Forgetting to add lights to the scene
Not positioning lights correctly for desired effect
Using too many lights which can impact performance
exercises.prerequisites: Completion of previous Three.js scene setup exercise.
exercises.description: Add lights and advanced materials to create realistic 3D objects.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html><head><title>Lights</title><style>body{margin:0}</style></head><body>
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/three@0.160.0/build/three.min.js"></script>
<script>
const scene = new THREE.Scene();
const camera = new THREE.PerspectiveCamera(75, window.innerWidth/window.innerHeight, 0.1, 1000);
const renderer = new THREE.WebGLRenderer();
renderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
document.body.appendChild(renderer.domElement);

const ambientLight = new THREE.AmbientLight(0x404040);
scene.add(ambientLight);
const directionalLight = new THREE.DirectionalLight(0xffffff, 1);
directionalLight.position.set(5, 5, 5);
scene.add(directionalLight);

const geometry = new THREE.SphereGeometry(1, 32, 32);
const material = new THREE.MeshStandardMaterial({ color: 0x00ff00, metalness: 0.5, roughness: 0.5 });
const sphere = new THREE.Mesh(geometry, material);
scene.add(sphere);
camera.position.z = 5;

function animate() {
  requestAnimationFrame(animate);
  sphere.rotation.y += 0.01;
  renderer.render(scene, camera);
}
animate();
</script></body></html>
exercises.hint: Add AmbientLight and DirectionalLight, then use MeshStandardMaterial for physically-based rendering.

exercises.title: Complex Geometries
exercises.preambleIntro: Create complex 3D shapes using Three.js geometries. Learn to work with spheres, toruses, and how to group multiple objects together for complex compositions.
keyConcepts: Relative Transformations: How child objects inherit parent transforms
commonPitfalls: Not providing enough segments for smooth curved surfaces
Forgetting to add groups to the scene
Not understanding how rotations affect grouped objects
Overlapping geometries creating z-fighting artifacts
exercises.prerequisites: Understanding of Three.js scenes, materials, and basic geometries.
exercises.description: Work with various Three.js geometries like spheres, toruses, and custom shapes.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html><body><script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/three@0.160.0/build/three.min.js"></script>
<script>
const scene = new THREE.Scene();
const camera = new THREE.PerspectiveCamera(75, window.innerWidth/window.innerHeight, 0.1, 1000);
const renderer = new THREE.WebGLRenderer();
renderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
document.body.appendChild(renderer.domElement);

const light = new THREE.DirectionalLight(0xffffff, 1);
light.position.set(5, 5, 5);
scene.add(light);
scene.add(new THREE.AmbientLight(0x404040));

const group = new THREE.Group();
const sphere = new THREE.Mesh(new THREE.SphereGeometry(0.5, 32, 32), new THREE.MeshStandardMaterial({color: 0xff0000}));
const torus = new THREE.Mesh(new THREE.TorusGeometry(0.7, 0.2, 16, 100), new THREE.MeshStandardMaterial({color: 0x00ff00}));
torus.rotation.x = Math.PI / 2;
group.add(sphere, torus);
scene.add(group);
camera.position.z = 5;

function animate() {
  requestAnimationFrame(animate);
  group.rotation.y += 0.01;
  renderer.render(scene, camera);
}
animate();
</script></body></html>
exercises.hint: Use Group to combine multiple geometries. Try SphereGeometry, TorusGeometry, and others.

exercises.title: Camera Controls
exercises.preambleIntro: Add orbit controls for interactive 3D viewing. OrbitControls allow users to explore your 3D scenes from any angle using mouse or touch input.
keyConcepts: Mouse Interaction: Left-click to rotate, right-click to pan, scroll to zoom
Camera Limits: Constraining rotation and zoom ranges
commonPitfalls: Forgetting to import OrbitControls from examples/jsm
Not calling controls.update() in the animation loop when damping is enabled
Setting inappropriate zoom limits that block the view
Not handling window resize events
exercises.prerequisites: Understanding of Three.js cameras and scenes.
exercises.description: Implement OrbitControls to allow users to rotate, zoom, and pan the camera.
exercises.starterCode:

<html><body><script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/three@0.160.0/build/three.min.js"></script>

// TODO: Import and add OrbitControls

exercises.solution:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html><body><script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/three@0.160.0/build/three.min.js"></script>
<script type="module">
import { OrbitControls } from 'https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/three@0.160.0/examples/jsm/controls/OrbitControls.js';

const scene = new THREE.Scene();
const camera = new THREE.PerspectiveCamera(75, window.innerWidth/window.innerHeight, 0.1, 1000);
const renderer = new THREE.WebGLRenderer();
renderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
document.body.appendChild(renderer.domElement);

const controls = new OrbitControls(camera, renderer.domElement);
controls.enableDamping = true;

const geometry = new THREE.BoxGeometry(2, 2, 2);
const material = new THREE.MeshNormalMaterial();
const cube = new THREE.Mesh(geometry, material);
scene.add(cube);
camera.position.z = 5;

function animate() {
  requestAnimationFrame(animate);
  controls.update();
  renderer.render(scene, camera);
}
animate();
</script></body></html>
exercises.hint: Import OrbitControls from the examples/jsm folder and pass the camera and renderer.domElement to it.

exercises.title: Procedural Terrain
exercises.preambleIntro: Create procedural terrain using PlaneGeometry and vertex manipulation. Learn the fundamentals of procedural generation - creating complex shapes from algorithms rather than manual modeling.
keyConcepts: Vertex Manipulation: Modifying individual points to create shapes
BufferGeometry Attributes: Accessing and modifying geometry data
Noise Functions: Using math to create natural-looking randomness
Normal Recalculation: Updating lighting after modifying geometry
commonPitfalls: Not providing enough segments for smooth terrain
Forgetting to call computeVertexNormals() after modifying vertices
Not understanding the vertex indexing system
Creating terrain that's too flat or too extreme
exercises.prerequisites: Solid understanding of Three.js geometries and materials.
exercises.description: Generate a 3D terrain landscape using noise functions and vertex displacement.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html><body><script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/three@0.160.0/build/three.min.js"></script>
<script>
const scene = new THREE.Scene();
const camera = new THREE.PerspectiveCamera(75, window.innerWidth/window.innerHeight, 0.1, 1000);
const renderer = new THREE.WebGLRenderer();
renderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
document.body.appendChild(renderer.domElement);

const light = new THREE.DirectionalLight(0xffffff, 1);
light.position.set(0, 10, 0);
scene.add(light);
scene.add(new THREE.AmbientLight(0x404040));

const geometry = new THREE.PlaneGeometry(20, 20, 50, 50);
const vertices = geometry.attributes.position;
for (let i = 0; i < vertices.count; i++) {
  const x = vertices.getX(i);
  const y = vertices.getY(i);
  vertices.setZ(i, Math.sin(x * 0.5) * Math.cos(y * 0.5) * 2);
}
geometry.computeVertexNormals();

const material = new THREE.MeshStandardMaterial({ color: 0x00ff00, wireframe: false });
const terrain = new THREE.Mesh(geometry, material);
terrain.rotation.x = -Math.PI / 2;
scene.add(terrain);

camera.position.set(0, 10, 15);
camera.lookAt(0, 0, 0);

function animate() {
  requestAnimationFrame(animate);
  terrain.rotation.z += 0.001;
  renderer.render(scene, camera);
}
animate();
</script></body></html>
exercises.hint: Use PlaneGeometry with many segments, then modify the Z coordinates of vertices using Math.sin and Math.cos for wave patterns.

exercises.title: 3D Particle Galaxy
exercises.preambleIntro: Build a stunning 3D particle galaxy using Points and BufferGeometry. Particle systems are used everywhere in 3D graphics - from stars to fire to magic effects!
keyConcepts: Vertex Colors: Assigning colors to individual particles
commonPitfalls: Not creating positions array with correct size (particleCount * 3)
Forgetting to use Float32Array instead of regular arrays
Not setting the correct attribute stride (3 for xyz coordinates)
Creating too many particles and impacting performance
exercises.prerequisites: All previous exercises. This combines many concepts!
exercises.description: Create a beautiful rotating particle galaxy with thousands of stars.
exercises.solution:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html><body style="margin:0"><script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/three@0.160.0/build/three.min.js"></script>
<script>
const scene = new THREE.Scene();
const camera = new THREE.PerspectiveCamera(75, window.innerWidth/window.innerHeight, 0.1, 1000);
const renderer = new THREE.WebGLRenderer();
renderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
document.body.appendChild(renderer.domElement);

const particlesGeometry = new THREE.BufferGeometry();
const particlesCount = 5000;
const posArray = new Float32Array(particlesCount * 3);
const colorsArray = new Float32Array(particlesCount * 3);

for(let i = 0; i < particlesCount * 3; i++) {
  posArray[i] = (Math.random() - 0.5) * 100;
  colorsArray[i] = Math.random();
}

particlesGeometry.setAttribute('position', new THREE.BufferAttribute(posArray, 3));
particlesGeometry.setAttribute('color', new THREE.BufferAttribute(colorsArray, 3));

const particlesMaterial = new THREE.PointsMaterial({
  size: 0.3,
  vertexColors: true,
  transparent: true,
  opacity: 0.8
});

const particlesMesh = new THREE.Points(particlesGeometry, particlesMaterial);
scene.add(particlesMesh);

camera.position.z = 50;

function animate() {
  requestAnimationFrame(animate);
  particlesMesh.rotation.y += 0.001;
  particlesMesh.rotation.x += 0.0005;
  renderer.render(scene, camera);
}
animate();
</script></body></html>
exercises.hint: Create a BufferGeometry, populate it with random positions using Float32Array, and render with Points and PointsMaterial.
